conclusion: Objects A and B move through the air and are placed down at the location of objects C, D, E, and F due to gravity.
Object A is shown as a piece of fabric positioned above two gray blocks labeled C and D.
Object B is shown as a piece of fabric positioned above two brown blocks labeled E and F.
When object A lands, gravity will pull it straight down until its fabric touches the two gray blocks (C and D).
The cloth of object A cannot pass through the blocks, so it settles on their tops and then hangs around their vertical sides, producing two neighboring 'tents' or peaks.
Between and beside the blocks C and D, the cloth of object A continues to sag, forming folds and valleys.
When object B lands, the same process happens over the two brown blocks (E and F).
The fabric of object B meets the tops of E and F, then drapes downward, wrapping their edges and settling onto the table everywhere it is not supported.
After a moment, everything stops moving: the cloths rest on the blocks and table with characteristic peaks over C–D and over E–F and gentle folds elsewhere.
Both cloths come to rest draped over their respective underlying blocks; each pair of blocks produces two raised peaks with the surrounding cloth sagging and folding naturally under gravity.
